comments.raw_text:
User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US) AppleWebKit/534.16 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/10.0.648.114 Safari/534.16
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.2.12) Gecko/20101026 Firefox/3.6.12 ( .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0E)

Usually if you type text into form fields, then navigate away from the page, then press the back button to go back, the text should still be there.

However, in firefox, if you use javascript to insert another form element somewhere in the page, all forms below the dynamically inserted form will no longer remember typed in text as they should.

See http://jsfiddle.net/NUC3w/7/ for a demo.

In firefox, enter data in the 2 fields, click the link and then click your back button. The second form input value isn't remembered. Comment out the javascript insertion of the form, and everything works normally.

It works as expected in Chrome and IE8.

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
Included test page and steps in details.
Actual Results:  
Field forgets typed in value.

Expected Results:  
Field remembers typed in value.
comments.creator: Spines11@gmail.com

It works as expected in Chrome and IE8.

comments.text: See this with Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:6.0a1) Gecko/20110428 Firefox/6.0a1, possibly Javascript engine
comments.creator: tdowner@mozilla.com

comments.author: tdowner@mozilla.com
bzbarsky@mit.edu
comments.text:
We use the form's index in the document as part of the state restoration key.  Yes, it fails in some cases... but the alternative would be to restore state into the wrong form in other cases.

Ideas on how to make this work in general quite welcome!
comments.creator: bzbarsky@mit.edu
